defs.docs: Window storage and interfacing traits.

attributes.value: deny(missing_docs)
deny(missing_copy_implementations)
/ Window storage and interfacing traits.
/ The [`Window`](./trait.Window.html) trait is the minimum interface required for event loop.
/ All backends usually support this trait.
/ The [`AdvancedWindow`](./trait.AdvancedWindow.html) trait
/ is the maximum interface that can be provided,
/ while still staying consistent between backends. Not all backends implement
/ `AdvancedWindow`; check your backend's documentation to see whether it implements
/ this trait.
/ The [`WindowSettings`](./struct.WindowSettings.html) structure is the preferred way of building
/ new windows in Piston. It uses the `BuildFromWindowSettings` trait,
/ which backends implement to handle window creation and setup.
/ The [`OpenGLWindow`](./trait.OpenGLWindow.html) trait is used to provide low-level
/ access to OpenGL through the abstract Piston API.
/ The [`Size`](./struct.Size.html) structure is used throughout Piston to store window sizes.
/ It implements some conversion traits for convenience.

defs.name: NoWindow
defs.docs: A window without user interface, often used in server event loops.

attributes.value: / A window without user interface, often used in server event loops.
/ This structure holds just enough state to return values that were set.
/ The size can be changed because the event loop does not emit
/ [`Render`](../event_loop/trait.RenderEvent.html)
/ events when the width or height is zero.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Creates a new `NoWindow`.

attributes.value: / Creates a new `NoWindow`.

defs.name: ProcAddress
defs.docs: The type of an OpenGL function address.

attributes.value: / The type of an OpenGL function address.
/ Note: This is a raw pointer. It can be null!
/ See [`OpenGLWindow`](./trait.OpenGLWindow.html) for more information.

defs.name: Size
defs.docs: Structure to store the window size.

attributes.value: / Structure to store the window size.
/ The width and height are in *points*. On most computers, a point
/ is 1:1 with a pixel. However, this is not universally true. For example,
/ the Apple Retina Display defines 1 point to be a 2x2 square of pixels.
/ Normally, the consideration of points vs pixels should be left to the
/ host operating system.

defs.name: width
defs.docs: The width.

attributes.value: / The width.

defs.name: height
defs.docs: The height.

attributes.value: / The height.

defs.name: Position
defs.docs: Structure to store the window position.

attributes.value: / Structure to store the window position.
/ The width and height are in *points*. On most computers, a point
/ is 1:1 with a pixel. However, this is not universally true. For example,
/ the Apple Retina Display defines 1 point to be a 2x2 square of pixels.
/ Normally, the consideration of points vs pixels should be left to the
/ host operating system.

defs.name: x
defs.docs: The x coordinate.

attributes.value: / The x coordinate.

defs.name: y
defs.docs: The y coordinate.

attributes.value: / The y coordinate.

defs.name: BuildFromWindowSettings
defs.docs:
Constructs a window from a [`WindowSettings`](./struct.WindowSettings.html)
 object.

attributes.value: / Constructs a window from a [`WindowSettings`](./struct.WindowSettings.html)
/ object.
/ It is used by [`WindowSettings::build`](./struct.WindowSettings.html#method.build).
/ Note that the backend's implementation of this may differ from its implementation

defs.name: build_from_window_settings
defs.docs: Builds the window from a `WindowSettings` object.

attributes.value: / Builds the window from a `WindowSettings` object.
/ # Errors
/ See your backend's documentation for details about what kind of
/ error strings can be returned, and the conditions for error.

defs.name: Window
defs.docs: Trait representing the minimum requirements for defining a window.

attributes.value: / Trait representing the minimum requirements for defining a window.
/ This trait defines all the behavior needed for making an event loop.
/ An example of a working event loop can be found in the Piston-Tutorials
/ repository under getting-started, or in the event loop examples.

defs.name: set_should_close
defs.docs: Tells the window to close or stay open.

attributes.value: / Tells the window to close or stay open.

defs.name: should_close
defs.docs: Returns true if the window should close.

attributes.value: / Returns true if the window should close.

defs.name: size
defs.docs: Gets the size of the window.

attributes.value: / Gets the size of the window.

defs.name: swap_buffers
defs.docs: Swaps render buffers.

attributes.value: / Swaps render buffers.
/ When this is set to false, this method must be called manually
/ or through the window backend. By default it is set to true, so
/ usually it is not needed in application code.

defs.name: wait_event
defs.docs: Wait indefinitely for an input event to be available from the window.

attributes.value: / Wait indefinitely for an input event to be available from the window.

defs.name: wait_event_timeout
defs.value: pub fn wait_event_timeout(&mut Self, Duration) -> Option<Input>
defs.docs:
Wait for an input event to be available from the window or for the
 specified timeout to be reached.

attributes.value: / Wait for an input event to be available from the window or for the
/ specified timeout to be reached.
/ Returns `None` only if there is no input event within the timeout.

defs.name: poll_event
defs.docs: Polls an input event from the window.

attributes.value: / Polls an input event from the window.
/ Return `None` if no events available.

defs.name: draw_size
defs.docs: Gets the draw size of the window.

attributes.value: / Gets the draw size of the window.
/ This is equal to the size of the frame buffer of the inner window,
/ excluding the title bar and borders.
/ This information is given to the client code through the
/ [`Render`](../input/enum.Event.html) event.

defs.name: AdvancedWindow
defs.docs: Trait representing a window with the most features that are still generic.

attributes.value: / Trait representing a window with the most features that are still generic.
/ This trait is implemented by fully featured window back-ends. When possible,
/ reduce the trait constraint to `Window` to make the code more portable.
/ The `Sized` trait is required for method chaining.

defs.name: get_title
defs.docs: Gets a copy of the title of the window.

attributes.value: / Gets a copy of the title of the window.

defs.name: set_title
defs.docs: Sets the title of the window.

attributes.value: / Sets the title of the window.

defs.name: title
defs.docs: Sets title on window.

attributes.value: / Sets title on window.
/ This method moves the current window data,
/ unlike [`set_title()`](#tymethod.set_title), so
/ that it can be used in method chaining.

defs.name: set_capture_cursor
defs.docs: Sets whether to capture/grab the cursor.

attributes.value: / Sets whether to capture/grab the cursor.
/ This is used to lock and hide cursor to the window,
/ for example in a first-person shooter game.

defs.docs: Sets whether to capture/grab the cursor.

attributes.value: / Sets whether to capture/grab the cursor.

defs.name: show
defs.docs: Shows the window.

attributes.value: / Shows the window.
/ If the platform does not support this, it will have no effect.

defs.name: hide
defs.docs: Hides the window.

attributes.value: / Hides the window.
/ If the platform does not support this, it will have no effect.

defs.name: get_position
defs.docs: Gets the position of window.

attributes.value: / Gets the position of window.

defs.name: set_position
defs.value: pub fn set_position<P: Into<Position>>(&mut Self, P)
defs.docs: Sets the position of window.

attributes.value: / Sets the position of window.
/ Has no effect if the window no longer has a position.

defs.name: position
defs.value: pub fn position<P: Into<Position>>(Self, P) -> Self
defs.docs: Sets the position of window.

attributes.value: / Sets the position of window.
/ Has no effect if the window no longer has a position.
/ This method moves the current window data,
/ unlike [`set_position()`](#tymethod.set_position), so
/ that it can be used in method chaining.

defs.name: OpenGLWindow
defs.docs: Trait for OpenGL specific operations on a window.

attributes.value: / Trait for OpenGL specific operations on a window.
/ OpenGL uses a strategy called "function pointer loading"
/ to hook up the higher level graphics APIs with the OpenGL
/ driver. Which function pointers to load depends on the
/ hardware capabilities and version of OpenGL. By using the
/ [`OpenGLWindow`](trait.OpenGLWindow.html)
/ trait, the higher level graphics API can load
/ functions from the window backend with the version set up
/ using the `WindowSettings` structure.
/ For more information about function pointer loading, see
/ https://www.opengl.org/wiki/Load_OpenGL_Functions

defs.name: get_proc_address
defs.docs: Returns the address of the specified OpenGL function if it exists.

attributes.value: / Returns the address of the specified OpenGL function if it exists.
/ If the function does not exist, it returns a null pointer.

defs.name: is_current
defs.docs: Returns true if this window's gl context is the current gl context.

attributes.value: / Returns true if this window's gl context is the current gl context.

defs.name: make_current
defs.docs: Make the window's gl context the current gl context.

attributes.value: / Make the window's gl context the current gl context.

defs.name: WindowSettings
defs.docs: Settings structure for window behavior.

attributes.value: / Settings structure for window behavior.
/ This structure stores everything that needs to be customized when
/ constructing most windows. This structure makes it easy to create multiple
/ windows with the same settings, and it also makes piston's multiple backends
/ easier to implement for piston devs.

defs.name: new
defs.value: pub fn new<T: Into<String>, S: Into<Size>>(T, S) -> WindowSettings
defs.docs: Creates window settings with defaults.

attributes.value: / Creates window settings with defaults.
/ - samples: 0
/ - fullscreen: false
/ - exit_on_esc: false
/ - vsync: false
/ - srgb: true
/ - resizable: true
/ - decorated: true
/ - controllers: true

defs.name: build
defs.value: pub fn build<W: BuildFromWindowSettings>(&Self) -> Result<W, String>
defs.docs: Builds window from the given settings.

attributes.value: / Builds window from the given settings.
/ The return value is ambiguous, to allow for operation on multiple
/ backends. Clients should explicitly name the return type. See the
/ Guide to using Piston Windows for more info and examples.
/ # Errors
/ This function will return an error if your backend returns an error.
/ See your backend's documentation on `build_from_window_settings()`
/ for more details.

defs.name: get_maybe_opengl
defs.docs: Gets the OpenGL version of built windows.

attributes.value: / Gets the OpenGL version of built windows.
/ If None is returned, the default OpenGL version is being used. This
/ is often a forward compatible version of OpenGL::V3_2 or
/ higher that works with newer versions of graphics libraries.
/ For more information about the OpenGL setting, see the
/ [`OpenGLWindow`](trait.OpenGLWindow.html) trait.

defs.name: set_maybe_opengl
defs.docs: Sets OpenGL version of built windows.

attributes.value: / Sets OpenGL version of built windows.
/ If None is passed, the default OpenGL version is used. This
/ is often a forward compatible version of OpenGL::V3_2 or
/ higher that works with newer versions of graphics libraries.
/ For more information about the OpenGL setting, see the
/ [`OpenGLWindow`](trait.OpenGLWindow.html) trait.

defs.name: maybe_opengl
defs.docs: Sets OpenGL version of built windows.

attributes.value: / Sets OpenGL version of built windows.
/ If None is passed, the default OpenGL version is used. This
/ is often a forward compatible version of OpenGL::V3_2 or
/ higher that works with newer versions of graphics libraries.
/ For more information about the OpenGL setting, see the
/ [`OpenGLWindow`](./trait.OpenGLWindow.html) trait.
/ This method moves the current window data,
/ unlike [`set_maybe_opengl()`](#method.set_maybe_opengl),
/ so that it can be used in method chaining.

defs.name: set_opengl
defs.docs: Sets OpenGL version of built windows.

attributes.value: / Sets OpenGL version of built windows.
/ For setting the OpenGL version back to default, see
/ [`set_maybe_opengl()`](#method.set_maybe_opengl).
/ For more information about the opengl setting, see the
/ [`OpenGLWindow`](./trait.OpenGLWindow.html) trait.

defs.name: opengl
defs.docs: Sets the OpenGL version of built windows.

attributes.value: / Sets the OpenGL version of built windows.
/ For setting the OpenGL version back to default, see
/ [`maybe_opengl()`](#method.maybe_opengl).
/ For more information about the opengl setting, see the
/ [`OpenGLWindow`](./trait.OpenGLWindow.html) trait.
/ This method moves the current window data,
/ unlike [`set_opengl()`](#method.set_opengl),
/ so that it can be used in method chaining.

defs.name: get_srgb
defs.docs: Gets whether built windows should use hardware accelerated color conversion.

attributes.value: / Gets whether built windows should use hardware accelerated color conversion.
/ If true, the graphics hardware uses customized circuitry
/ to convert colors from sRGB to linear color space in graphics
/ shaders, and then converts pixel fragments back to sRGB
/ depending on the color format of the frame buffer. This feature
/ is supported by most graphics hardware and set to true by
/ default.
/ See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SRGB for more information.

defs.name: set_srgb
defs.docs: Sets whether built windows should use hardware accelerated color conversion.

attributes.value: / Sets whether built windows should use hardware accelerated color conversion.
/ See [`get_srgb()`](#method.get_srgb) for more information about
/ the srgb setting.

defs.name: srgb
defs.docs: Sets whether built windows should use hardware accelerated color conversion.

attributes.value: / Sets whether built windows should use hardware accelerated color conversion.
/ See [`get_srgb()`](#method.get_srgb) for more information about
/ the srgb setting.
/ This method moves the current window data,
/ unlike [`set_srgb()`](#method.set_srgb),
/ so that it can be used in method chaining.
